LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  India 
   
The Proposal  A  Modernizing  Government  and  Fiscal  Reform  cluster  loan 
comprising two subprograms, is proposed for Kerala to support 
the  Kerala  government  in  attaining  the  financial  means  and 
capability  to  deploy  resources  in  a  transparent,  accountable, 
predictable, and equitable manner; to build on the social gains 
achieved in the past; and to create the enabling environment for 
pro-poor growth.  
 
The Program   
   
  Rationale  Kerala  is  recognized  nationally  and  internationally  for  creating 
exceptional  social  opportunities  for  its  citizens.  These 
achievements are remarkable, as they resulted from public action 
of a democratically elected state government and conscious civil 
society.  However,  chronic  and  acute  fiscal  stress  due  to  the 
state's mounting debt burden over the last decade has severely 
threatened  these  achievements'  sustainability.  The  recent 
participatory poverty assessment carried out in Kerala identified 
fiscal stress as undermining the state's capacity to steer pro-poor 
growth. The assessment highlighted some challenges facing the 
Kerala government in its mission to eradicate poverty: lack of 
economic opportunity, weaknesses in targeting programs for the 
poor, and deteriorating health and education quality.  
  
The  Kerala  government  has  formulated  the  Modernizing 
Government Program (MGP) and entered into two agreements 
with  the  central  Government  to  address  the  fiscal  crisis  and 
undertake structural reforms, including in the power sector. The 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  Government  of  the 
Netherlands will provide technical and financial assistance to help 
the Kerala government implement its reforms.  
 
  Objectives and  The Program will contribute to the Kerala government's poverty 
Scope  reduction and development strategy contained in the Tenth Five-
Year  Plan  (2002–2007)  and  MGP.  The  Program  is  designed 
around four themes and results:  
(i)  Achieve fiscal sustainability, including initial policy 
actions to enable power sector reform.  
(ii)  Improve the quality, equity, and value for money of 
services  provided  by  the  state  government  and 
local self-governments (LSGs). 
(iii)  Improve the targeting and quality of the poverty 
reduction programs and social services. 
(iv)  Strengthen the functions and structures of the state 
government and LSGs to increase accountability, 
responsiveness, transparency, and efficiency.

ii   
 
Fiscal reform includes the following: 
(i)  creation  of  an  enabling  environment  for  power 
sector reform,  
(ii)  reform of state-level public enterprises (SLPEs),  
(iii)  introduction  of  a  medium-term  fiscal  framework 
(MTFF),  
(iv)  improvement  of  budgeting  and  expenditure 
management, and  
(v)  strengthening  of  tax  and  nontax  revenue 
mobilization.  
 
Service delivery will focus on design and implementation of an 
integrated set of policies on service delivery, social audit, and 
asset  renewal.  Poverty  reduction  will  focus  on  strengthening 
poverty monitoring and reporting, improving the quality and the 
targeting  of  subsidies,  and  designing  and  implementing  an 
antipoverty  sub-plan.  Strengthening  of  state  and  local 
governments will facilitate decentralization, redeploy surplus state 
government staff, build institutional and human resource capacity, 
and enact laws to make government information readily available 
to the people of Kerala.  
 
Developed  through  extensive  consultation,  the  Program  is  a 
partnership  among  the  central,  Kerala,  and  Netherlands 
governments and ADB. The Program is based on the fiscal reform 
initiatives contained in the agreements between the central and 
state governments, and in Kerala's MGP. The partnership has a 
common policy matrix and program monitoring arrangement. ADB 
and the Government of the Netherlands have actively participated 
in  the  Kerala  government's  design  process,  and  the  Program 
draws on the earlier technical assistance (TA) support provided to 
the  Kerala  government  by  ADB  and  the  Government  of  the 
Netherlands. The design draws on the implementation experience 
and  lessons  learned  from  ADB’s  public  sector  resource 
management and power sector programs in Gujarat and Madhya 
Pradesh.  
 
Under subprogram 1, policies to achieve the program objectives 
will be established, with emphasis on implementation, monitoring 
impact,  and  establishing  accountability  for  the  new  policies. 
Implementation will begin in priority areas and scaled up after 
review in subprogram 2. During the midterm review of subprogram 
1, criteria will be developed to prioritize projects for subprogram 2. 
The prior actions to be taken in the power sector should improve 
the  financial  health  of  the  Kerala  government  and  create  an 
enabling environment for a power sector development program. 
The  Kerala  government  will  plan  reform  measures  for 
nonoperational manufacturing SLPEs in subprogram 1.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a (i) proposed 
program cluster concept for the Modernizing Government and Fiscal Reform in Kerala Program 
in India (the Program), (ii) proposed loan to India for subprogram 1 of the Program, and (iii) 
proposed administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a grant to be provided by the 
Government of the Netherlands for subprogram 1 of the Program. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  The fiscal performance of most Indian states has deteriorated rapidly during the last 
decade in large part because rigid administrative procedures and supply-driven approaches to 
service delivery have made quick adjustment to changing macroeconomic circumstances very 
difficult. The consolidated fiscal deficit of the central and state governments amounted to 9.6% 
of gross domestic product (GDP) in fiscal year (FY) 2001. The states account for about half of 
this  deficit.  Real  interest  rate  increases  associated  with  financial  sector  liberalization, 
deregulation of private investment decision making, cumulative impacts of weak regulatory and 
financial oversight in power and other utility sectors, and pursuit of populist fiscal policies have 
all contributed to state fiscal deterioration. Civil service and public sector wages have generally 
grown much faster than the economy over the last 5 years. 
 
3.  The growing fiscal imbalances of states have been reflected as a decline in the quality of 
state expenditure patterns as nonproductive expenditures gradually replaced growth-inducing 
and socially productive investments. The consolidated current (revenue) account balance of the 
states thus shifted from surpluses during the 1980s to substantial deficits during the 1990s. In 
Kerala, widening fiscal current account deficits went along with an increase in salary, interest, 
and pension outlay as a percentage of revenue receipts (from 71.0% in FY1996 to 92.5% in 
FY2001), while capital spending declined drastically. The Kerala government thus has greatly 
diminished resources for discretionary spending, including on programs to ensure that the poor 
have access to basic services. 
 
4.  The emerging crisis of state debt and expenditure composition has led the central 
Government to propose a number of important reform initiatives (described in the next section) 
intended to reverse fiscal decline, strengthen regulatory institutions, and improve expenditure 
allocations.  
 
5.  Kerala’s macroeconomic performance has been dominated over the last 5 years by 
three major trends: severe fiscal stress; difficulties in adjusting the state's primary economic 
base  to  changing  external  circumstances,  including  increased  competition;  and  increased 
reliance  on  foreign  remittances  from  nonresident  workers,  fueling  private  consumption 
expenditures. The Kerala economy grew at an annual real rate of 5.7% in FY1994–FY2001.1 
Over the same period, real growth rate was 2.2% per annum in the primary sector, 6.1% in the 
secondary sector, and 7.4% in the tertiary sector. Recent investor surveys rank the state low in 
investment attractiveness. The low levels of foreign direct and aggregate private investment in 
the state indicate a weak investment climate.  
 
6.  Due to deteriorating fiscal performance, the Kerala government has difficulty meeting its 
developmental commitments. Increasing deficits and compression of nonwage and noninterest 
expenditures have led to inadequate infrastructure investment and a decline in operation and

III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance2  
8.  Kerala is a small state of 32 million inhabitants, on the west coast of India, and noted for 
having the highest social indicators in the country. The state is also remarkable for its high rate 
of  participation  in  political  life  and  high  indicators  of  social  capital.  Despite  the  state's 
outstanding social accomplishments, Kerala's prospects for prosperity are threatened by chronic 
fiscal stress, manifested in the nondelivery of essential services to the poor and marginalized; 
inadequate funding for new infrastructure investment; inadequate resources devoted to O&M; 
mounting arrears to contractors, which undermine competitive procurement; rising debt-to-
GSDP ratio; accumulated and mounting losses of the more than 100 SLPEs; rapidly increasing 
stock  of  loans  to  SLPEs  and  boards  backed  by  guarantees;  and  KSEB's  acute  financial 
deterioration.  
 
9.  Poverty. The state has made important strides in reducing poverty through local self-
governments (LSGs) and the State Poverty Eradication Mission called “Kudumbashree.” The 
Kudumbashree model of self-employment with community support is based on successful 
experiments in urban and rural poverty initiatives in the 1990s and organizes women from 
households below the poverty line into a three-tier structure of self-help groups to tackle the 
various dimensions of poverty. The Kerala government recently evaluated the Kudumbashree 
model with assistance from the Netherlands Government, and the findings will be used to 
update the approach and institutional arrangements to reduce poverty in Kerala.  
 
10.  A recent participatory poverty assessment3 identified major pockets of acute poverty, 
concentrating mainly among fishing communities, tribal households, households of cashew nut 
and coir workers, and communities dependent on seasonal employment. Unemployment among 
the educated young is a major social concern. The assessment highlighted the very high degree 
of indebtedness among the poor, who rely heavily on informal credit systems with interest rates 
as high as 326% per annum. The declining quality of public health and education threatens past 
achievements and future prospects, and imposes additional costs on the poor.  
 
11.  Service  delivery  to  the  poor  is  constrained  by  weak  targeting  and  prioritizing  of 
vulnerabilities among the poor. The state's survey of poor households, used to identify program 
beneficiaries, indicates that 43% of the population lived below the poverty line—far higher than

12.  Kerala faces four main long-term challenges for an effective poverty reduction strategy:  
 
(i)  Increase the rate of economic growth while enhancing the conditions to allow 
broad  participation  in  the  benefits  of  growth,  and  avoiding  environmental

(ii)  Ensure that access to health and education is further broadened and their quality

(iii)  Find ways to identify and target the poorest and most excluded groups.  
(iv)  Improve access by the poor to credit at affordable rates. 
 
13.  Tax and Nontax Revenue. In the past decade, the  growth of state tax and nontax 
revenue has not been buoyant, because of the difficulty of effectively taxing consumption 
financed by foreign remittances, a neglect of administration of tax collection and its reform, and 
inadequate commitment to periodic rate adjustment for user fees. Nontax revenues in Kerala 
are low in comparison to the neighboring states. A special committee constituted by the Kerala 
government in 1998 to advise on mobilizing nontax revenues have stressed the need for radical 
improvements in this area. The transformation of state sales tax into a nationwide system of 
state-operated value-added tax (VAT) including taxation of services is proposed to take effect 
from  April  2003.  This  initiative,  in  which  Kerala  is  participating,  is  intended  to  increase 
compliance,  drastically  simplify  rates,  and  yield  neutrality  benefits  arising  from  interstate 
harmonization and coordination. Other fiscal distortions that undermine economic efficiency 
include  high  stamp  duty  rates  and  inadequate  implementation  of  property  tax  by  local 
governments.  
 
14.  Budgeting  and  Expenditure  Management.  The  budgeting  system  and  supporting 
institutional framework for expenditure management and control are not working effectively. 
Contributing causes of increased fiscal stress have been a rigid approach to budgeting, implicit 
reliance on a supply-driven priority setting, and a wish to maximize the size of the plan 
independent of resource constraints. An imbalance between policy objectives and available 
resources is at the heart of much of the financial indiscipline and operational weakness. 
Aggregate financial discipline of the budget process is weak, and hard expenditure targets are 
underdeveloped as evidenced by the tradition of having up to three supplementary budgets per 
year.  Managerial  autonomy  is  limited,  and  improved  cost-effectiveness  goes  unrewarded. 
Payment arrears thus build up, and flexibility to vary strategic allocations is lacking. Institutional 
processes  to  review  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  expenditures  are  weak.  Fiscal 
transparency is inadequate, leading to inadequate financial control. Annual submissions that 
accompany budget proposals from departments on staff strength cannot be verified by the 
Finance Department. The lack of timely reports and the absence of a midyear assessment of 
budget and budgetary outcomes deprive decision makers of the intelligence needed to make 
informed choices about future spending and revenue generation.  Capital and maintenance 
outlays are also neglected because they are discretionary expenditures.

15.  Power Sector. The Kerala government manages and regulates the state's power sector 
through KSEB, the monopoly supplier of electricity, which was established under the Electricity 
(Supply)  Act  of  1948.  KSEB  supplies  6.6  million  consumers.  Increased  consumption  of 
electricity during the last decade has outpaced internal supply, requiring increased reliance on 
high-cost  sources  of  external  supply.  The  financial  performance  of  KSEB  has  rapidly 
deteriorated, resulting in large implicit subsidies leading to a mounting stock of state guaranteed 
debt. The absence of an independent regulator, and noneconomic interventions in tariff setting 
has contributed to inadequate cost recovery. High rates of transmission and distribution losses, 
reported to be at least 30% of generated supply, high cost of purchase of thermal energy, high 
cost of finances, cost overrun of projects, and operational inefficiency have deepened the 
financial crisis. Although the Kerala government raised power tariffs by 25% in mid-2001, the 
rate of increase fell far short of the 60% increase that was proposed in the White Paper on State 
Finances.  A  further  increase  took  effect  in  early  October  2002,  necessitated  by  KSEB's 
worsening cash flow resulting from the adverse impact of the low monsoon on availability of 
hydropower. 
 
16.  State-Level  Public  Enterprises.  Kerala  has  111  active  SLPEs.  The  public  utility 
subcomponent, including KSEB, accounts for the largest shares of investment (68%) and 
employment (47%), and for the highest share in the aggregate loss of the state public sector. 
SLPEs are vulnerable to national and international competition that has recently intensified as a 
result of India’s World Trade Organization commitments. SLPEs' productivity has also declined 
owing to inadequate investment. The special interdepartmental enterprises reform committee 
(ERC) was established with an advisory mandate to develop an action plan to restructure and 
reform  SLPEs.  The  ERC  brought  out  its  first  approach  paper  on  SLPE  reform  and  has 
determined criteria to prioritize SLPEs for restructuring.  
 
17.  Local Self-Government. Kerala is recognized nationally and internationally as having 
pioneered  decentralization  in  the  1990s,  giving  broad  powers  to  LSGs  to  improve service 
delivery and make government more accessible to the poor. The LSGs have made considerable 
progress  in  this  regard  and  in  providing  housing,  water,  and  sanitation.  However, 
decentralization is incomplete. The Kerala government has a policy to transfer a third of its plan 
funds to LSGs but continues to employ and pay the wage bill for staff in key social sectors and 
has not transferred funds for O&M of assets. The fiscal crisis has created fund shortfalls. As a 
consequence, there is a serious backlog in the maintenance of schools, hospitals, and water 
supply systems that have been transferred to LSGs. Decentralization entails new lines of 
accountability and reporting. Without interfering, the Kerala government can assist by providing 
performance  information  to  LSGs  and  build  independent  monitoring  mechanisms  such  as 
parent-teacher associations, health boards, and various civil-society watchdogs. The Kerala 
government has undertaken a study funded by the Netherlands Government to analyze and 
summarize the experience of the past 6 years. The LSG action plan and capacity building 
program also draw on findings of the review and the recommendations of the State Planning 
Board (SPB).   
 
18.  Service Delivery. The quality of basic services by LSGs and the Kerala government has 
been deteriorating for a number of reasons: (i) diffused accountability caused by the incomplete 
transfer of local government functions from the Kerala government, (ii) inadequate measures 
and lack of adequate resources to address the capacity-building requirements of LSGs, (iii) 
emphasis on spending plan funds on new initiatives at the expense of allocating money for 
O&M, (iv) nonplan and a significant component of the plan funds going to pay staff salaries, (v) 
lack of a citizen-centered service delivery culture, (vi) few opportunities for the community to

5 
audit the services provided by LSGs and the Kerala government, and (vii) lack of mechanisms 
to track the public expenditure that goes into service delivery.  
 
19.  Core Government Functions.5 The public sector operates with little concern for results, 
an almost complete absence of a service culture, overlap and duplication across levels of 
government, and policies riding on fragmented systems and processes of government.6 Policy 
formulation and coordination are diagnosed as paying insufficient attention to transparency and 
formal  consultation  processes.  Inadequate  attention  is  given  to  policy  implementation, 
enforcement, and monitoring. Norms for civil service staffing have not been fundamentally 
reviewed in many decades, which contributes to excessive staffing in major infrastructure 
departments such as irrigation and public works. Frequent transfer of senior officers leads to 
reduced employee efficiency as well as reduced opportunities for staff to develop subject matter 
competencies. Payrolls, pensions, and personal records have not been computerized or linked, 
thus deterring effective management decision making on human resource issues.  
 
20.  Many powers and functions related to delivery of essential services and local economic 
development have been transferred from the Kerala government to LSGs. Unfortunately, the 
transfer did not result in the restructuring of the Kerala government, which now has more than 
17,000 surplus staff.7 A further 5,000 should be transferred to LSGs along with requisite 
functions.  The  Kerala  Administrative  Reforms  Committee  has  made  a  number  of  sound 
recommendations  to  remove  impediments  to  public  sector  performance.  These 
recommendations will need to be implemented in a coordinated manner across all levels of 
government. 
 
B.  The Kerala and Central Governments' Strategy  
21.  The Partnership between the Kerala and Central Governments. The fiscal and 
structural problems described above are also experienced by many other states and have led 
the central Government to propose a number of important reforms. One is the States’ Fiscal 
Reform Facility, which provides grant resources and a broad agenda for structural reforms to 
help states meet fiscal targets. Eighteen states have received additional funding from the central 
Government on the basis of improved fiscal performance. Participating states have agreed to 
develop a medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) that quantifies the impacts of reforms and 
ensures that policies are consistent with sustainable future outcomes for debt and deficit levels. 
A  second  incentive  program  to  encourage  structural  reform  in  operational  and  financial 
improvement in the power sector is the Accelerated Power Development and Reform Program, 
which provides concessional financing to states for power improvements against a time-bound 
set of reform milestones. The Kerala government has reached agreements with the central 
Government on reform measures for the power sector, which are reflected in a memorandum of 
understanding (MOU) between the Kerala government and Ministry of Power, dated 20 August 
2001; and fiscal reform measures under the letter of shared fiscal goals and objectives from the 
Kerala government to the Ministry of Finance, dated 4 February 2002.8 The Kerala government, 
along with KSEB, is participating in a national agreement for the securitization of arrears owed 
by state electricity boards to central power utilities.

39.  Adopting the MTFF Approach. The Kerala government’s failure to link policy, planning, 
and budgeting has created a situation where these processes are fragmented and planning is 
limited to an annual exercise for plan expenditure. By developing a consistent and realistic set 
of resource envelopes, the MTFF will improve resource allocation to strategic priorities and 
increase commitment to predictability of policy and funding over the short to medium term so 
that departments can plan ahead and programs can be sustained. 
 
40.  The Kerala government finalized its Medium-Term Fiscal Reform Plan (MTFRP) in 2001 
as part of the agreement with the central Government. A revised set of fiscal projections as of 
November 2002 (see Appendix 7) under the MTFRP has been agreed on by the Kerala and 
central governments that explicitly incorporate the costs of adjustment of the Program, including 
those associated with core government functions, LSGs, poverty reduction and minimum-needs 
program, and SLPE reform. In addition, the Kerala government updates the MTFRP annually, 
along with semiannual reporting on performance against targets to help build accountability and 
to ensure that decision making takes place within the parameters of the fiscal plan in the 
MTFRP.   
 
41.  Fiscal Responsibility Legislation. The Kerala government has decided to introduce 
fiscal  responsibility  legislation  to  strengthen  the  state's  capacity  to  (i)  promote  fiscal

institutionalize a medium-term perspective into  the budgetary process, (iv) adopt corrective 
policies to deal with emerging imbalances and fiscal slippage, (v) reduce deficits, (vi) adjust 
taxes and expenditure to shortfalls in budgetary targets more quickly, and (vii) clarify for the 
public the medium-term implications of budget policy. Fiscal responsibility legislation has been 
prepared by the Kerala government and is based partly on the central Government’s fiscal 
responsibility legislation. Karnataka State has already passed a fiscal responsibility act, and the 
Punjab and Maharashtra governments have proposed similar legislation. Fiscal responsibility 
legislation  in  Kerala  will  be  enacted  and  brought  into  force  in  2003  and  implemented  in 
subprogram 2.

management capacity.

50.  Service Delivery Policy. Planning service delivery is a complex process, which should 
balance  competing  service  demands,  link  closely  with  financial  planning  and  performance 
management systems, reflect users' needs, and involve the community and stakeholders. 
Kerala poses special challenges. While LSGs have the mandate to deliver a significant number 
of basic services, the transfer of resources, functions, and responsibilities is incomplete. For 
example, primary health care centers in village panchayats continue to have to rely on the state 
government through the Health Department for health care staff, purchase of drugs and other 
consumables, and many other service delivery-related decisions. In some areas, difficulties 
arise from the lack of clear responsibility between state and local governments to provide 
services.  
 
51.  Under subprogram 1, the Kerala government and  LSGs will develop and implement a 
service delivery policy framework. Its main features will include (i) customer-oriented service 
delivery, (ii) a code of practice for result-oriented management in public service delivery, (iii) 
statutory rights of access  by citizens to service delivery information, (iv) enforcement and 
compliance measures, (v) external audit to strengthen accountability and transparency, (vi) 
social audit for grassroots assessment of service delivery, (vii) monitoring and public reporting 
on performance, (viii) institutional arrangements to implement the policy, and (ix) costs of 
implementing the policy in the priority areas. Funds will be made available from the Kerala 
government and LSG budgets to support independent organizations that will measure service 
delivery performance. Responsibility for translating the central policy into sector policies or 
location-specific policies will be with line departments/agencies and LSGs. 
 
52.  The Kerala government has approved the establishment of a service delivery policy unit 
reporting to the MGP secretary in the Chief Secretary’s Office to design and oversee the 
implementation of the service delivery policy. The unit will be operational before the end of the 
year. The first phase of the implementation of the service delivery policy will focus on land 
transactions in revenue and registration departments, issuance of building permits, and a 
selected number of taluk offices. At the LSG level, the policy will first be implemented in a 
primary health care center in 14 village panchayats, three municipalities, and one corporation. 
Implementation of the service delivery policy will need to be linked to the budget preparation 
processes of the Kerala government and LSGs to ensure consistency in priorities between the 
areas targeted for service delivery improvements and budget allocations.

experience. The results of social audits will inform the service delivery and asset  renewal 
policies and plans. 
 
55.  The social audit policy will be implemented in health, education, water supply, and 
sanitation in subprogram 1. The key outputs from subprogram 1 will be a social audit policy 
approved through broad-based stakeholder consultation and social audit reports for a focused 
group of services, and published in a form readily accessible to the public.  
 
56.  Asset  Renewal.  Operational  efficiency  and  service  delivery  are  constrained  by 
equipment and infrastructure that have not been maintained. Assets essential to provide basic 
public services such as primary health and child nutrition services are often in a state of 
disrepair. The lack of attention given to O&M, combined with the fund shortage and rules 
prohibiting use of plan funds for maintenance, has led to deterioration of assets required to 
provide basic public services.  
 
57.  In the FY2002 budget, the Kerala government announced the creation of an asset 
renewal fund to rehabilitate assets holding back the provision of essential public services. 
Subprogram 1 will help implement an asset renewal policy linked to service delivery and social 
audit policies, and focus on assets required to deliver social services. Key policy components 
will include criteria for prioritizing services, establishing simple asset management systems, and 
making budget provisions to maintain assets. An independent team with suitable resources will 
audit the asset renewal program and report on performance. Criteria for the equitable sharing of 
the asset renewal fund will also be developed and commence under subprogram 1. 
 
58.  The Kerala government has prepared an asset renewal policy, which is being subjected 
to  wider  consultation  with  LSGs  and  other  stakeholders.  The  institutional  and  funding 
arrangements to implement the policy and track its performance will be particularly important to 
ensure integration with the Kerala government and LSG priorities and with the service delivery 
improvement plans. The policy's recommendations to facilitate a trouble-free and regular asset 
renewal system include (i) amending financial rules to ensure that user charges and other local 
charges can flow back to maintain assets, (ii) encouraging maintenance contracts through build-
operation-maintenance arrangements, and (iii) rationalizing and making transparent the system 
of spares and consumables and their distribution.

government and supported by an asset renewal fund and appropriate institutional arrangements 
to administer, manage, and monitor the policy; (ii) restoration of assets in priority areas; and (iii)

from the budget for future asset maintenance in priority areas where assets have been restored.

audit policies and to allow access to information held by the Kerala government, LSGs, and 
SLPEs. The legislation will set out institutional mechanisms for enforcement and appeals, and

Five-Year Plan.

State  and  centrally  sponsored  schemes  for  poverty  reduction  are  implemented  with  little

V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
89.  Vision. The Program will contribute to the Kerala government’s overall reform agenda. 
Subprogram 1 will enable the Kerala government to build vital capacity in modernizing of 
policymaking,  monitoring  the  poor's  access  to  government  services,  and  using  modern 
expenditure management and budgeting techniques. With these enhanced capacities in place, 
the state can discourage wasteful expenditures and redirect resources to program activities with 
greater  social  and  economic  benefits.  Subprogram  2  will  build  upon  the  reforms  and 
strengthened institutional foundation developed in subprogram 1. The benefits expected from 
subprogram 1 are outlined below by thematic area. 
 
90.  Fiscal Sustainability.  The Program will help execute the fiscal correction measures 
agreed on between the central and Kerala governments. For the power sector, the program 
measures will create sound regulatory and financial foundations for reform. The policy reforms 
will support a renewed power sector investment program, partly funded under proposed ADB 
lending. Implementation of the Kerala government’s SLPE action plan will reduce the Kerala 
government’s  liabilities,  consolidate  and  improve  the  efficiency  of  the  public  sector  while 
creating the space for private sector investment. The MTFF will bring about a number of 
benefits: (i) improvements in the predictability of the resources available, (ii) adoption of new 
budgets at the start of the financial year by line department, (iii) increased transparency in 
budget reporting and scrutiny, and (iv) an expanded and institutionalized MTFF system that 
realistically  identifies  multiyear  resource  envelopes  and  expenditure  commitments  to  help 
political leaders make informed choices about expenditures over competing uses over time.  
 
91.  Improvement  of  Service  Delivery  Quality.  The  Program  will  create  the  enabling 
environment and fiscal facility to improve the quality and quantity of services provided by the 
state and LSGs. Service delivery improvement projects will be piloted in priority social sector 
service delivery points, and lessons learned will feed into a wider program in subprogram 2. The 
Kerala  government  will  create  the  enabling  legislation  to  become  more  transparent  and 
accountable by providing relevant, timely, and useable information to citizens. Subprogram 2 
will have initiatives focusing on the implementation of the Right to Information Act.  
 
92.  Strengthening of Poverty Reduction Programs.  The Program will help the Kerala 
government target the poor, improve efficiency of poverty reduction projects and programs, 
provide better information on the effectiveness of subsidies for the poor, strengthen the poverty 
institutional  network  for  program  delivery  and  poverty  monitoring,  and  develop  a  poverty 
subplan through a consultative process under subprogram 2.  
 
93.  Strengthening of Functions and Structures of the Kerala Government and LSGs. 
The expected benefits include (i) a civil service that will change behavior by focusing on results

23 
and performance; (ii) introduction of sound, transparent, and consultative policymaking that links 
policy, planning, and budgets; (iii) more effective utilization of staff and containment of staff 
costs; (iv) better information to plan and manage human resources; (v) a program to upgrade 
skills of staff for redeployment; (vi) a state government restructured to become more efficient, 
effective, and accessible, and to create the enabling environment for local government to deliver 
its mandate; (vii) improved accountability and authority by LSGs over human resources; (viii)

B.  Impacts 
94.  Poverty Impact. An IPSA was carried out by the Center for Development Studies, a 
leading think tank on social issues in India, particularly in Kerala (Appendix 6). The study 
concludes that the policy measures proposed for the power sector and SLPEs do not have a 
major adverse impact on the poor. One of the initiatives under the MTFF—to curtail non-interest 
government expenditure as a percentage of GSDP—has the potential to generate an adverse 
impact on the poor. However, such adverse impact is strongly mitigated by a number of 
comprehensive initiatives as part of MGP: the LSG action plan and the antipoverty measures. In 
addition, the action under the Program are intended to identify and curtail wasteful expenditure 
that in turn will free up additional resources for high priority social spending targeted to the poor. 
The impact of the reform on women will be diverse. SLPE reform might have an adverse impact 
on women in some regions and some sectors, but overall the resources released should benefit 
women.  Similarly,  the  poverty  reduction  schemes,  particularly  the  Kudumbashree  and 
microcredit will benefit poor women. Policy measures for SSN and VRS should mitigate the

A.  Background,  Recent  Performance,  Fiscal,  and  Systemic  General  Government 
Issues 
 
1.  Kerala has experienced chronic fiscal stress with mounting contingent liabilities over the 
last decade. The ratio of interest payments to total state revenue rose from 17.5% in FY1994 to 
21.3% in FY2002. State fiscal performance deteriorated substantially from FY1998 to FY2000, 
leading to a record gross fiscal deficit of 7% of the gross state domestic product (GSDP) in 
FY2000.  Although  some  indicators  of  budget  performance  have  since  improved,  the 
fundamental threat of a deepening fiscal crisis remains because of unresolved contingent 
liabilities caused by deteriorating finances of state-owned enterprises and boards, and because 
of the deferral of structural government reforms needed to ensure efficient and effective service 
delivery. Indeed, the stock of state-level public enterprises (SLPEs) debt with guarantee has 
grown at an accelerated rate in the last 2 years. With support from the central Government, 
progress is being made in strengthening incentives for states to undertake fiscal reforms, and 
the Kerala government has responded to these incentives by committing itself to an ambitious 
reform agenda.  
 
2.  Although a strong fiscal correction is necessary to restore state finances to a sustainable 
path, higher real growth could also strengthen fiscal performance. The real annual growth rate is 
estimated to be 5.7% in FY1994–FY2001,1 but the corresponding rate for the primary sector is a 
mere 2.2%. Kerala’s traditional economic base, consisting of agriculture and related processing 
industries, is adjusting with difficulty to increased competition. Kerala's main remaining engines 
of economic growth are remittances from nonresident workers, and the burgeoning, but still 
small, tourism and information technology (IT) industries. However, these growth sectors and 
sources of spending provide few opportunities and benefits for the poor, who derive their 
livelihood overwhelmingly from agriculture, fishing, and associated basic processing industries. 
The state has not attracted much secondary manufacturing despite its highly skilled workforce.  
 
3.  Maintaining real annual growth at 5–6% and continuing to reduce poverty will depend 
critically on the state’s ability to provide key infrastructure support to industry and agriculture 
and to ensure adequate, well-targeted, and high-quality supplies of social services such as 
education and primary health. Addressing the fundamental structural issues undermining state 
finances  thus  appears  to  be  key  to  restoring  sustainable  finances  and  establishing  solid 
government support for renewed broad-based and pro-poor growth for the entire economy.  
 
B.  Constraints and Issues in Developing a Sustainable Fiscal Strategy  
 
4.  The uncontrolled growth of government guarantees for borrowing by public sector and 
other bodies has emerged as one of the state’s most important fiscal problems. Borrowings 
guaranteed by the Kerala government totaled Rs118 billion by end March 2002, equivalent to 
15.2% of GSDP. Guarantees have grown in magnitude primarily due to inadequate commitment 
to cover costs in power, and weak financial control over key state-level public enterprises 
(SLPEs) and boards. The risk of a substantial proportion of these guarantees being called has 
increased because guarantee-backed loans have been used recently to fund operating deficits 
and working capital to loss-making enterprises, rather than projects yielding a healthy social rate 
of return. Another type of contingent liability for the Kerala government is its pension burden,

8.  A  public  consensus  is  emerging  in  favor  of  national  and  state  policies  on  fiscal

the quality of loans so that over the medium term, the guarantee fees will be sufficient to

reduce gross fiscal deficit and public debt to sustainable levels within 5 years. Other announced

C.  Expenditure Management and Budgeting  
 
11.  The  budget-making  system  and  supporting  institutional  framework  for  expenditure 
management and control do not encourage efficiency. The development of a modern budgetary 
system that will deliver sustainable fiscal outcomes to better match needs and resources has 
been supported under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA).2 The TA 
advisory work and state’s own reform initiatives have been merged into a multiyear strategic 
implementation plan (designed as part of Modernizing Government Program [MGP]) for phased 
improvement on budgetary and expenditure management policies and institutional renewal. 
 
12.  Fiscal stress has been worsened by a rigid approach to budgeting, implicit reliance on a 
supply-driven priority setting, and an intent to maximize the size of the plan independently of 
resource constraints. An imbalance between policy objectives and available resources is at the 
heart  of  much  of  the  financial  indiscipline  and  weaknesses  in  operational  performance. 
Aggregate financial discipline of the budget process is weak, and hard expenditure targets are 
undermined by the practice of permitting up to three supplementary budgets. The budgeting 
process  does  not  evaluate  the  incremental  recurrent  costs  of  plan  projects,  nor  does  it 
encourage departments to make trade-offs among alternative current and capital uses of funds. 
Except in formulation of the 5-year plan, the current institutional approach to budgeting is 
inflexible. Institutional processes to review the efficiency and effectiveness of programs are 
underdeveloped.   
 
13.  Fiscal  transparency  is  also  inadequate,  leading  to  weak  financial  control.  A  major 
contributor is the practice of booking unspent allocations to departments as spent at the end of 
each  fiscal  year.  The  lack  of  timely  reports  to  the  executive  and  legislative  branches  of 
government on actual annual budget outturns, and absence of midyear fiscal performance 
assessments deprive decision makers of the information needed to make informed choices 
about future spending and resource availability. Capital and maintenance outlays are also badly 
neglected under the current approach to budgeting, in part because of a lack of commitment to 
multi-year budgeting. Maintenance suffers, particularly because nonwage recurrent expenditure 
provides one of the few sources of discretionary spending.

F.  Local Self-Government  
 
22.  The 73rd and 74th amendments to the Indian Constitution mandate the establishment of 
local governments as the third tier of government, and list the functions that state governments 
can devolve to local governments.  Local governments are envisaged as partners of the central 
and state governments in development. The spirit of the Constitution demands creation of LSG 
institutions, implying a move toward greater autonomy. Poverty reduction is of prime concern for 
local governments. Kerala has gone much farther than any other state in transferring functions 
and  human  and  financial  resources,  and  has  followed  an  unorthodox  strategy  of 
decentralization. Through a "big bang" approach, powers and resources were transferred all at 
once in 1995–1996.  
 
1.  Problems and Current Situation Analysis3  
23.  Local governments have been given a wide range of development responsibilities, 
including agriculture and allied sectors, traditional industries, poverty reduction, social welfare, 
women’s  development,  uplift  of  socially  disadvantaged  groups,  provision  of  connectivity, 
management of health and educational facilities, environmental sanitation, and provision of 
drinking water. To meet these responsibilities, local governments are being given one third of 
the Kerala government’s plan resources. However, the way local government plans for and 
utilizes plan funds for development has a number of weaknesses and problems: (i) absence of a 
strategic vision of development; (ii) key stakeholders not participating in the planning process; 
and (iii) schemes and plans often prepared as repetition of earlier government programs without 
critical analysis of the current situation, resource endowments, potential for development, and 
likely returns. The methods adopted to choose schemes or fix priorities have been informal and 
not based on interpretation of available data. Local governments have not been very successful

maintenance plan for the assets transferred to them or the assets created by them; asset 
management is weak. Assets that have not been maintained have been transferred from the 
state government, and budgets for operation and maintenance have not.

is  inflated  due  to  political  and  bureaucratic  largesse  and  the  desire  to  corner  subsidies.

25.  Service Delivery. Kerala's celebrated social sector achievements are threatened by the

direct bearing on their well-being. The management of transferred institutions such as hospitals, 
schools, and transferred public offices is inadequate. Citizen interface with LSGs is not smooth 
as the procedures for service provision are not client oriented. Local governments have not 
developed a constructive relationship with nongoverment organizations. 
 
26.  The  important  issues  to  be  considered  in  health  care  provision  are  (i)  hospital 
management; (ii) quality of primary health care; (iii) lack of doctors and paramedical staff in rural 
areas; (iv) centralized procurement procedures with no delegation, resulting in inadequate 
supply of drugs, equipment, and other consumables; (v) centralized decision making, resulting 
in  delayed/inappropriate  actions;  and  (vi)  absence  of  a  system  for  accountability  and 
measurement of outcomes and impacts. The major issues that adversely impact the functioning 
of  government  and  aided  schools  are  ineffective  implementation  of  educational  policies, 
suboptimal utilization of funds, inadequate local control and monitoring of education, attitudinal 
problems of teachers, and absence of periodic reorientation of curriculum and syllabus. As part 
of the day-to-day administration, the public has to approach local governments for matters such 
as obtaining birth and death certificates, getting building licenses, and registering institutions. 
However, the harassment and delays the public faces undermine the credibility of the local 
government system. 
 
27.  Financial  Management.  The  financial  management  by  local  governments  has 
traditionally  been  weak.  A  coordinated  and  intensive  program  is  required  to  address  the 
following problems:  
(i)  The mode of assessment of property, profession, and entertainment taxes is 
cumbersome and opaque. This, coupled with lack of clear instructions on tax 
assessment, has affected realization of taxes due. Nontax revenue, particularly 
the fees, fines, and rates, are not revised as revision of rules is slow and difficult. 
Collection of user charges is weak. 
(ii)  Fiscal transfers from government are delayed due to the fiscal crisis. 
(iii)  The systems and procedures for budget preparation and budget execution are 
extremely weak, and although the budgets are open documents, they are not 
easily understood by the layman. The accounting system is cumbersome and 
opaque. 
(iv)  Audit of local governments is not independent as it is done by the Local Fund 
Audit Department under the Finance Department of the Kerala government. The

suggestions is slow.  
 
28.  Public Management. The administration of local governments has deteriorated over the 
years  due  to  pressure  of  work,  absence  of  systems,  and  low  skill  of  personnel.  Local 
governments still follow outmoded office administration systems, which create opportunities for 
corruption. An office management system needs to be established and rules of business for 
transacting  the  work  of  elected  bodies  need  to  be  in  place.  The  staffing  profile  of  local 
governments has not been changed despite significant additional responsibility. Redeployment 
of staff from the Kerala government, based on the principle of work and worker going together, 
has not been completed, resulting in staff shortages, especially in engineering and account 
keeping. The placement and tenure of local government staff is not based on any norms, 
affecting remote local governments, which have unfilled positions. Local government control 
over staff is uncertain, and procurement is very slow and costly. The  Public Works Manual, 
which  governs  execution  of  public  works  by  local  governments,  is  archaic  and  allows 
tremendous discretion to technical supervisors.  
 
29.  Functioning  of  Institutions.  Kerala  adopted  the  model  of  setting  up  strong, 
independent institutions, particularly to reduce state government control over local governments. 
Some of the institutions have been functioning well. However, resources are needed and a 
coordinated program of action is required to deal with the problems facing the State Election 
Commission, State Finance Commission, Ombudsman, State Development Council, appellate 
tribunals, and Kerala Urban Development Finance Corporation. The Rural Development Board 
has become redundant, and the district planning committees have not shown the capacity to 
plan in an integrated manner for the overall development of the district. The Kerala Institute of 
Local Administration, which is responsible for local government training, has insufficient capacity 
and no resources.   
 
30.  Policy Environment. The local government policy environment has several problems: 
(i) lack of functional clarity between the tiers of local government in respect of agriculture and 
allied sectors; (ii) industries and poverty reduction; (iii) ignorance of the roles of different state 
government departments in relation to local governments; (iv) heads of departments in the 
Kerala government not willing to relinquish responsibilities to local governments; (v) continued 
existence  of  parallel  structures  such  as  development  authorities;  (vi)  existence  of  parallel 
schemes, especially of the Agriculture Department; (vii) functional overlaps between the rural 
development and LSG departments; and (viii) delays in implementing the recommendations of 
the Second State Finance Commission. 
 
31.  In response to the comprehensive analysis of problems facing local government, the 
Kerala government has set up a special task team in MGP to develop and implement a project 
to support the institutionalization of the local government system. The task team has developed 
a  strategic  implementation  plan  through  support  provided  by  the  Government  of  the 
Netherlands. The State Planning Board has also made a number of recommendations that the 
Kerala government recently approved, concerned with institutionalizing the system of local 
government. The resulting LSG action plan is key to the Program. The Swiss and Netherlands 
governments are helping build local government capacity, and the World Bank is funding 
research to look at the wider issue of sustainable fiscal decentralization.

G.  Kerala Government Reform Achievements  
 
32.  Since  the  publication  of  the  White  Paper  on  State  Finances  in 2001, the Kerala 
government has taken a number of measures to address the fiscal crisis and begin reform. The 
MGP steering committee, chaired by the chief secretary, was constituted in January 2002, and a 
full-time MGP secretary was appointed to coordinate and manage the Program. A high-powered 
committee  is  developing  a  reform  package  for  the  power  sector,  and  a  committee  was 
established in early 2002 to promote economic development. An investors’ meeting is planned 
for January 2003, raising awareness of the private sector to business opportunities in Kerala. 
The pilot project on "bridging the digital divide" is an initiative being implemented by the Kerala 
government in partnership with the private sector in Mallapurram district. The objective of the 
project is to improve IT literacy by having a structured capacity-building program to ensure that 
at least one member of every family in the state is able to send and receive electronic mail and 
to be able to use word processing and other basic IT tools. The other target is to ensure Internet 
access within a radius of 2 kilometers for all families. A unique feature of the project is the major 
role of the private sector and the minimal investment from the state government.   
 
33.  Fiscal Management. The Kerala government has been able to reduce the ratio of 
consolidated revenue deficits to revenue receipts by more than 17% during FY2001. The Kerala 
government has received the incentive fund from the central Government (as per the letter of 
shared fiscal goals and objectives) under the Medium-Term Fiscal Reform Facility. No new 
posts have been created, and 55 schools that have few learners and meet the closure criteria 
have been closed. The surrender of earned leave facility has been canceled and pension dues 
have been reduced through a reworking of the commutation formula. The surplus staff initiative 
has identified 17,000 surplus staff, and a net attrition rate of 1% has been maintained for the 
past year. Government orders have been issued for not sanctioning any new aided educational 
institutions  and  for  freezing  expansion  of  state-run  and  aided  schools.  Higher  technical 
education, including medical education, has been opened up for the private sector.  
 
34.  Revenue Mobilization. The Kerala government has taken several steps to augment tax 
collection, including (i) rationalization and simplification of tax structure; (ii) improvement and 
enhancement of tax compliance; (iii) faster disposal of appeals; (iv) speedy disposal of pending 
cases; (v) withdrawal of absolute stays granted by the Kerala government; (vi) computerization 
of revenue collection systems; (vii) periodic revision of user charges, and (viii) mobilization of 
national savings. The draft bill for levying a VAT, scheduled to be introduced in the Assembly in 
December 2002, will reduce the number of stages of appeal in tax dispute adjudication. 
 
35.  Power Sector. The Kerala government has established a State Electricity Regulatory 
Commission. A tariff hike was announced in early October 2002, estimated to reduce KSEB’s 
monthly cash flow deficit by Rs350 million. 
 
36.  Other Reforms. A program to reform the State Transport Corporation was initiated, and 
the Corporation's monthly losses have been reduced. An interim report from the law reform 
initiative proposing repeal of 82 laws has been submitted for public comment. A draft bill on the 
right to information is being vetted by the Law Department, and a combination of measures 
reflected in the new IT, industrial, and labor policies is designed to improve the enabling 
environment for private sector investment.  
 
37.  Local  Self-Governments.  The  Council  of  Ministers  has  approved  a  campaign  to 
strengthen LSGs, particularly by improving the function of Grama Sabhas and making elected 
heads and secretaries of LSGs accountable for service delivery through citizens’ charters and

SUMMARY POVERTY AND SOCIAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT 
 
This report—in the form of a narrative and matrixes—presents a preliminary assessment 
of the nature and magnitude of the likely impact on the poor of the reforms proposed under the 
program loan. The changing  poverty situation resulting from each component of the reform 
program needs to be studied to assess the full impact in the short-run as well as in the medium 
run.1 
 
A.  The Policy Issues 
 
1.  Kerala is well known for its high levels of literacy, especially among females, and low 
infant mortality (12 per 1,000 live births in 1997). Such achievements are thought to be made 
possible through "public action promoting a range of social opportunities relating inter alia to 
elementary education, land reforms, role of women in society, and widespread and equitable 
provision of health care and other public services."2 While the poverty level was comparable to 
the all-India level until the early 1980s, reduction since then has been rapid, reaching 13% in 
FY2000. 
 
2.  Kerala, with a per capita gross state domestic product (GSDP) of $450 , has done well in 
economic growth during the last 30 years compared to many other states, but its progress has 
not been commensurate with the high human capabilities built over the years. This growth has 
largely been led by the tertiary sector, the share in GSDP of which increased from 32% in 
FY1971to 58% in FY2001.3 The share of the secondary sector has shown hardly any change 
and remains around 21%. The rapid growth of the tertiary sector has been beneficial to the 
poor, and studies4 show that higher farm yields, higher state development spending, higher 
nonfarm output, and lower inflation all reduced poverty. Nonfarm output alone had differential 
elasticities across the states, and substantially higher elasticity for Kerala. Urbanization in an 
area will reflect the higher nonfarm growth, and the poor are expected to gain when they live in 
a more urbanized area. Kerala is not highly urbanized. Over 40 years the level of urbanization 
has increased from 15% to 26%, with the bulk of the increase taking place during 1981–1991. 
The most urbanized districts have over two thirds of the main workers in the nonprimary sector, 
and the least urbanized districts have less than one fourth in the nonprimary sector.  
 
3.  In Kerala the dependence of scheduled caste and scheduled tribes on agriculture is 
much higher than in many other states. The proportions overall  become very low for the 
scheduled tribe population, and the relationship has also become very weak with urbanization. It 
is evident that while scheduled caste population is able to take advantage of urbanization, to 
some extent scheduled tribe population is not. Districts with large numbers of scheduled tribe 
are the least urbanized and have shown practically no urban growth over the last 40 years.5 
 
4.  The lower urbanization and poor nonfarm growth in many districts have gone along with 
poor access to some of the basic services by the poor and higher dependence on agricultural 
labor. The least urbanized districts have a higher proportion of poor families dependent on

(ii)  Should  the  Kerala  government  carry  out  functions  in  the  conventional  way,

D.  Suggestions on How to Carry Out Poverty and Social Analysis in Kerala 
 
24.  The impact of the proposed reforms has been assessed within the framework of the 
poverty impact assessment matrix, which is a limited exercise, since the conclusions have been 
drawn on the basis of limited data and various earlier studies conducted for a variety of 
purposes. A seemingly more rigorous approach such as a computable general equilibrium 
modeling, assuming that the necessary inputs for such an exercise were available, would also 
be of limited use. The matrix at least throws some light on the nature of the trade-off between 
short-term adverse effects and medium-term likely improvements.  
 
25.  The probable impact of reforms on the poor in the short run and how poverty develops 
over  time  will  depend  on  a  number  of  factors,  the  most  crucial  factor  of  which  is  the 
effectiveness of SSNs. Changing poverty resulting from each component of the reform program, 
which includes the mitigating measures, thus needs to be studied to assess the full impact in the 
short and medium term. 
 
26.  The most important indicator for assessing poverty situation is income or consumption 
expenditure. The percentage of people below the poverty line is estimated on the basis of the 
large-scale sample surveys of household consumption expenditure conducted periodically by 
the National Sample Survey Organization. This data set can be used to estimate poverty rates 
only on a broad aggregate level. At the local level, data on income poverty is nonexistent, 
resulting in various proxies being suggested. Poverty is generally defined in terms of multiple 
dimensions where the indicators range from asset holding or access to public services to school 
enrollment rate. The effects of a VRS or a one-time settlement cannot be assessed in the short 
run by looking at withdrawal of children from school if education remains subsidized. Thus, a 
framework must be designed for impact analysis, taking into account the specificity of the 
program as well as the regional context.

27.  In Kerala, unlike in other Indian states, individuals and households almost equally share 
certain human development indicators across various income classes. The major impact on the 
poor is likely to be through changes in income-earning opportunities. Therefore, income remains 
the most important indicator, at least in the short and medium run. But reliable income data is 
costly to collect. Proxies are thus needed, and the benefit from using them has to be assessed 
in relation to the cost and benefit of using the original. If most of the proxies are very imperfectly 
correlated with the original, the original has to be used in spite of the high cost. Average number 
of days of employment along with real wages in certain main occupations, or some other 
indicators, may provide a good idea about income. A rigorous exercise is needed at the outset 
to identify indicators that are the best proxies of income poverty in Kerala. 
 
28.  It  is  possible  to  combine  various  indicators  to  form  a  suitable  poverty  and  social 
monitoring  system.  Various  government  and  nongovernment  agencies  and  individual 
researchers  have  made  numerous  attempts  to  do  so.  The  state’s  Rural  Development 
Department recently collected data on a number of indicators at the household level to identify 
households below the poverty line. The success of this massive effort is mixed, because 
adequate safeguards to minimize systematic misreporting were not built into the implementation 
design. However, with innovative methodological approaches, census data, along with such 
other sources as employment-unemployment surveys, agricultural censuses, surveys of small-
scale industries, and so on, can be combined to form a poverty monitoring system.

1.  Multiyear fiscal projections reflecting the program policy measures have been prepared 
in consultation with the Kerala government. These projections will form inputs into the Kerala 
government’s FY2004 budget in the context of the medium-term fiscal framework for fiscal

substantive adjustment costs associated with the Program, estimates of future deficits for the 
Kerala State Electricity Board under independent regulatory supervision, and outlays to mitigate

remedial capital expenditures for social infrastructure. 
 
2.  Program projections achieve (i) stabilization of the debt-to-gross state domestic product 
(GSDP) ratio and the state debt, plus power sector debt-to-GSDP ratio over the medium term; 
(ii) a gradual decrease in revenue deficit to 1.46% of GSDP by FY2005; and (iii) a consistent 
improvement in the primary balance leading to a primary surplus, starting in FY2004. The 
primary  balance  (deficit/surplus)  measures  how  current  actions  improve  or  worsen  Kerala 
government’s  net  indebtedness,  and  is  an  important  fiscal  indicator  for  evaluating  the 
sustainability of government deficits. Although a fiscal deficit can be run indefinitely, the primary 
balance should eventually become positive under prudent macroeconomic assumptions to 
ensure that the primary surplus covers at least part of the interest on debt. 
 
3.  The fiscal aspects of the Program focus on (i) consolidation of the public finances 
through revenue enhancement, notably by adopting a VAT; (ii) improvement in the “quality” of 
the fiscal balance by focusing on the composition of fiscal adjustment, including increased

Program  will  be  underpinned  by  a  performance  measurement  system  that  will  track  the 
performance of key results areas of the Program in a meaningful and transparent manner. The 
performance  indicators  will  comprise  input  and  output  and  process  indicators,  and  cover 
subprograms 1 and 2. The starting point for tracking performance will be the items in the policy 
matrix, which are also reflected in the program framework. However, as the Kerala government 
develops its capacity to monitor performance, the system will be enhanced to capture a wider 
range of indicators, including outcome indicators. Measures to monitor benefits will focus on 
service delivery improvements and access to information by the public, including monitoring by 
representatives of civil-society organizations.  
 
2.  The  aim  of  performance  measurement  is  to  improve  public  services,  reinforce 
accountability, and underpin effective working practices in the Kerala government and local self-
governments (LSGs). A performance measurement system will be established for the various 
projects in the Program by the project teams in consultation with relevant stakeholders. The 
Kerala government will receive technical assistance from the Government of the Netherlands to 
design and implement such a performance monitoring system.  
 
3.  The system will be designed for use in a variety of organizational settings, ranging from 
the Secretariat to LSGs. However, the consistent reporting cycle and reporting format will allow 
for  consolidation  and  comparison.  Performance  measures,  targets,  and  systems  will  be 
designed and implemented by line departments and LSGs. Project-based performance reports 
will be submitted via the MGP secretary to the MGP steering committee for approval. Once 
cleared by the steering committee, they will be submitted to the MGP Cabinet subcommittee. All 
performance reports will be published on the Kerala government web page. 
 
4.  The  performance  measures  will  have  several  audiences,  each  with  their  own 
requirements,  such  as  the  general  public,  MGP  steering  committee,  MGP  Cabinet 
subcommittee, and departmental and LSG heads. 
 
5.  The underlying principles that the Kerala government will have to bear in mind in 
designing an effective performance measurement system are that it must (i) have clarity of 
purpose, (ii) focus on the priority areas for improvement, (iii) have a balanced number of 
measures, (iv) be owned by the staff responsible for collecting and analyzing the data, (v) be 
scrutinized at a number of levels to challenge the focus and to ensure the robustness of the 
data, (vi) have systems of performance evolve over time and adapt to changing circumstances. 
and (vii) have measures for regular monitoring and reviews.  
 
6.  The performance measures will be purposeful, clearly defined, and easy to interpret. In 
choosing  measures,  consideration  will  be  given  to  measures  of  economy,  efficiency, 
effectiveness, quality, and value for money. Targets should be time specific, incorporate an 
element  of  comparison,  and  be  realistic.  These  considerations  are  often  summarized  as 
"SMART"—specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and timed. Central direction may be 
valuable to ensure that valid comparisons can be made, but local discretion should also be 
allowed to ensure that targets are set at a level appropriate to the organization.

Appendix 10  83 
7.  To ensure that the performance system is implemented in a phased manner, high-
priority areas for change must be identified, and the policy matrix will provide some direction in 
this regard. The Kerala government will need to consider how progress monitoring is to be 
linked  to  decision  making  either  in  the  project  or  the  MGP steering committee or by line 
departments and LSGs. Relevant targets are needed for those at the frontline, and focus should 
be on areas where performance is important and need improvement. For example, establishing 
a  performance  system  for  primary  health  care  centers,  linked  to  the  service  delivery 
improvement program, social audit, asset renewal, and the Right to Information Act could be 
useful starting points, whereby the system starts with some basic indicators and progressively 
widens in scope as the various policy measures and legislation are implemented.

RISK MITIGATION MEASURES 
 
A.  Program Purpose—Risk-Mitigating Measures  
 
1.  Support  to  Implementation  of  the  Modernizing  Government  and  Fiscal 
Reform Program 
(i)  The Cabinet subcommittee on modernizing government program (MGP) 
should have a meaningful role in program implementation, politicians and 
the  legislature  briefed  regularly  on  MGP  progress,  awards  given  for 
outstanding  service  delivery,  and  funds  channeled  to  encourage 
improvements and innovations to raise MGP’s political profile. 
(ii)  A  small  team  of  senior  civil  servants  should  be  responsible  for 
modernizing policymaking. 
(iii)  Sound program/project management principles should be adopted for 
MGP. 
(iv)  Performance measures and achievements for all initiatives should be 
publicized.  
(v)  Internal and external communications should receive investment. 
(vi)  The reform program should be a standard agenda item at the weekly 
Cabinet meetings. 
(vii)  The success of the partnership should be publicized at the political and 
official  levels,  and  agreements  between  the  central  and  Kerala 
governments adapted to accommodate the changing context. 
(viii)  The  Kerala  government  should  conduct  periodic  checks  on  investor 
attitudes and take appropriate action. 
(ix)  Unions should be brought into the reform process early on. 
(x)  The State Planning Board should produce regular performance reports on 
funding for high-priority reform initiatives and their impact. 
(xi)  Local  self-governments  (LSGs)  should  publicize  their  performance  in 
service delivery, poverty reduction, and democratic processes. 
(xii)  The Kerala government should adopt a concerted strategy to redirect 
savings  in  nonpriority  areas  to  social  sectors,  and  publicize  savings 
realized. 
 
B.  Output Risk-Mitigating Measures 
 
1.  Power Reform  
 
(i)  The state legislature should be briefed on the fiscal reform program, 
including medium-term power reform measures. 
(ii)  The Finance Department should consider how other states have dealt 
with settlement of dues and liabilities and payment of subsidies. 
(iii)  Consumers and media should be briefed on power reform.

Appendix 11  85 
 
2.  Medium-term Fiscal Framework and Associated Legislation 
 
(i)  A dedicated finance task team is mandated to lead fiscal reform and 
execution  of  recommendations  proposed  by  the  Supporting  Fiscal 
Reforms in Kerala Technical Assistance (TA). 
(ii)  The  Kerala  government  should  access  TA  to  build  capacity  in 
implementing and reviewing MTFF. 
(iii)  The  central  and  Kerala  government  meetings  to  review  progress  in 
achieving targets in agreements should be regular and structured, and 
results  of  meetings  and  progress  in  achieving  targets  should  be 
published. 
(iv)  The Kerala government should access TA to design and implement a 
payroll and personnel computerized system. 
(v)  The  Finance  Department  should  ensure  that  there  are  sound  job 
descriptions and competency profiles before the unit is set up. 
 
3.  Revenue-Enhancement Measures  
 
(i)  Ensure  that  TA  is  available  to  develop  a  sound  revenue-forecasting 
system. 
(ii)  Restructure the Finance Department and Commercial Tax Department to 
help  create  a  function  with  dedicated  staff  responsible  for  revenue 
forecasting. 
(iii)  Ensure  sound  project  management  for  successful  implementation  of 
value-added tax (VAT). 
(iv)  Seek political support for collection of sales tax arrears and publicize 
monthly analysis of collections and arrears. 
(v)  Publicize policy on indirect tax concessions and provide regular updates 
on the extent to which policy is followed. 
(vi)  Ensure  effective  support  and  training  for  the  rationalized  stamp  duty 
system. 
(vii)  Establish systems and training for the new system of property tax that are 
effective and timely with built-in measures for effective compliance.  
 
4.  Budget Preparation, Reporting, and Execution Processes Reformed 
 
(i)  Ensure that the Finance Department is restructured to deliver revised 
budget and expenditure management functions and that the restructured 
department has a sound capacity-building program. 
(ii)  Have a dedicated multidisciplinary team to steer budget and expenditure 
management reform.

(iii)  Pay attention to selection of the expert teams leading the reviews of the 
infrastructure  schemes/projects,  and  to  measures  to  ensure  that  the 
reviews  are  not  derailed  by  persons  working  on  the  schemes  and 
projects.

Service Delivery Policy 
 
(i)  Consider handing out service delivery awards. 
(ii)  Introduce service delivery policy.

(v)  Involve the Local Government Association.

6.  Surplus Staff Identified in the Secretariat and Departments and Redeployed 
in Accordance with Policy   
 
(i)  The Kerala government should set aside funds for retraining and reskilling 
staff and link this to the training policy and plan for civil servants. 
(ii)  A unit in the Personnel Department should be dedicated to redeployment 
of surplus staff.  
(iii)  A staff awareness and communications program should underpin the 
redeployment program. 
(iv)  A dedicated team is necessary to establish a distributed database of 
personnel records using a modern information technology-based system. 
An  off-the-shelf  package  should  be  considered  to  speed  up 
implementation and ensure value for money. 
 
7.  Staff Transfers on Basis of Civil Service Rules 
 
(i)  Adopt a transparent and effective reporting system for transfers that do 
not adhere to norms justifying basis for transfer. 
(ii)  Consider strengthening transfer norms and adopting transfer rules. 
 
8.  Functional Reviews in Priority Areas Completed 
 
(i)  Make the MGP steering committee responsible for ensuring that suitable 
appointments are made for the functional review unit. 
(ii)  Ensure  that  the  Kerala  government  accesses  TA  to  ensure  that  job 
descriptions are effective and training is provided to unit staff.

(iii)  Involve unions from the outset and begin a process involving capacity 
building to create the incentives and environment for change. Introduce 
sound change management measures. 
(iv)  Avoid  too  technical  an  approach  in  conducting  functional  reviews. 
Compromise  and  go  for  a  few  selective  areas  rather  than  entire 
departments. Look for quick wins and champions for reform. 
 
9.  Right-to-Information Legislation Enacted and Brought into Force 
 
(i)  Study what has and has not  worked in other states and internationally 
before finalizing the act. 
(ii)  Pay particular attention to implementation and the extent to which citizens 
can realize their rights. 
 
10.  Decentralization Process from the Kerala Government for Subprogram 1 
Completed   
 
(i)  Ensure that the LSG Department has clear responsibilities, accompanied 
by performance measures on the Department’s role in the LSG system. 
(ii)  The State Planning Board and the Second State Finance Commission 
need to continue to champion the LSG system and steer decentralization 
in an effective and timely manner.  
(iii)  The  Kudumbashree  model  needs  to  be  integrated  into  the  LSG 
institutional arrangements. 
(iv)  A dedicated multidisciplinary team from the Secretariat should establish 
the  human  resource  management  system  for  LSGs,  including  senior 
officials from the key departments involved in the transfer and chaired by 
the chief secretary. 
 
11.  Local Self-governments Strengthened 
 
(i)  The importance of the LSG audit needs to have a higher profile, and a 
senior manager in the  LSG Department should oversee the timely and 
effective implementation of LSG audit and follow-up, closely coupled with 
LSG capacity building in financial management, which should cover audit. 
(ii)  Investment is needed to establish/expand sound institutions for building 
and sustaining a system of local government. The Program must pay 
attention to this and the extent to which provision needs to be made in the 
budget to complete institutionalization of LSGs. 
(iii)  The  LSG  Department  should  be  a  priority  for  functional  review and 
capacity building.

(i)  Establish  a  multidisciplinary  team  comprising  external  and  internal 
stakeholders and women’s group representatives to lead and manage 
study on subsidies. 
(ii)  Ensure widespread consultation in developing proposals to improve the
